title: Theme and Meaning
content: Check whether the story has a clear theme and meaning: can it be described in one or two sentences (a logline), does it make a statement about values or beliefs, and does the subject resonate with the times?
items: Is the story relevant and easily described?
Is the story about something?
Does it make a statement about values or beliefs?
Can I encapsulate it in a sentence or two (what’s commonly called a “log line”)?
Does the subject resonate with the times?

title: Substance and Budget
content: Check whether the story’s scope fits a feature film: enough plot to sustain a feature without being overloaded, budget matches the expected audience, and the concept is inherently cinematic (rather than better as a play, novel, or short story).
items: Is the size and type of story suited to a feature film?
Does the anticipated budget match the size of the anticipated audience?
Is there enough plot material to sustain a feature film, but not too much?
Is the story cinematic by nature, or would it be more effective as a play? As a novel? As a short story?

title: Sympathy and Empathy
content: Check whether the audience will emotionally stay with the protagonist: empathy and caring are established for the principal character and are not split across multiple characters or shifted to the antagonist.
items: Do we care about the principal characters?
Does the protagonist draw us into the story emotionally?
Can audiences relate to the main character’s situation?
Is our sympathy focused on one character, and not split between two or more characters?
Does our sympathy stay with the protagonist, and not shift to the antagonist?

title: Believability
content: Check credibility and causality: events and character behavior feel realistic, the plot advances through character actions rather than coincidence, and the resolution is brought about by the protagonist (not outside intervention).
items: Does the story rely on credible human efforts?
Is the premise believable?
Are the events believable?
Do the characters behave realistically?
Does the plot rely on the characters’ actions, and not on coincidence?
Does the protagonist bring about the story’s resolution, so the ending does not rely on outside intervention?

title: Comprehension
content: Check comprehensibility and broad resonance: the story is unique yet accessible to general audiences, references are understandable, the depicted world is relatable, universal emotions are evoked, and the tone remains consistent.
items: Is the story unique, accessible to a general audience, and emotionally resonant?
Has the story been done before?  If so, have I given it a unique twist?
Will audiences understand the language, symbols, and references in the story?
Can audiences relate to the world depicted in the story?
Does the story elicit universal emotions?
Is the tone consistent?

title: Intention and Objective
content: Check clarity and consistency of the protagonist’s intention/objective: initial imbalance is established, motive is strong, the desire to restore balance is apparent within the first ~10 pages, the objective is clear by ~30 pages (in a 120-page script), sub-intentions serve the main intention, and the intention carries through to the end.
items: Is the protagonist strongly motivated, with a clear objective?
Are circumstances out of balance in the beginning?
Does the protagonist have a strong motive?
Is the protagonist’s desire to correct what is out of balance apparent within the first 10 pages?
Is it clear within the first 30 pages (in a 120-page script) what the protagonist intends to do?
Does the protagonist’s intention remain consistent?
Do all the sub-intentions further the main intention?
Does the protagonist’s intention continue to the end of the story?

title: Jeopardy and Obstacles
content: Check jeopardy and obstacles: the protagonist is in real danger of failing, success is made as difficult as possible, obstacles are credible (not contrived), the effort required matches the strength of the intention, and meaningful complications exist.
items: Is the protagonist in extreme danger of not achieving their objective?
Have I made the protagonist’s ability to achieve their objective as difficult as possible?
Are the obstacles credible, without seeming contrived?
Does the effort needed to overcome the obstacles match the strength of the protagonist’s intention?
Are there complications?

title: Conflict
content: Check whether conflict is focused and sustained: the antagonist is focused on the same objective, each scene contains clashing intentions, conflict centers on a pivotal character or object of desire and persists throughout, and the protagonist also faces internal psychological conflict.
items: Is the antagonist focused on the same objective as the protagonist?
Are there conflicting intentions in every scene?
Is the conflict centered on a pivotal character or object of desire?
Is this central conflict sustained throughout the script?
Are there conflicting psychological forces within the protagonist?

title: Anticipation and Momentum
content: Check anticipation and momentum: a question keeps the audience guessing, the central question holds from beginning to end, each scene generates anticipation for what follows, subplots overlap enough to keep the story moving, tension escalates, twists exist, and surprises are not telegraphed.
items: Is there always some question that keeps the audience guessing?
Does the central question stay the same from the beginning to the end?
Does each scene generate anticipation for the scenes that follow?
Do the subplots overlap sufficiently to keep the story moving?
Does tension gradually increase?
Are there any twists?
Have I been careful not to telegraph the surprises?

title: Orchestration
content: Check orchestration and unity: the theme is expressed in varied ways and pulled together at the end, events form a strong narrative through-line (not a collection of episodes), the script feels like one movie (not multiple), subplots serve the main plot, and pacing varies appropriately.
items: Is there a unity of theme, represented in a variety of ways, but pulled together at the end?
Do the events comprise a strong narrative through-line, not merely a collection of episodes?
Is my script one movie, not two or more separate movies?
Are there enough subplots to explore all relevant aspects of the theme?
Is the main plot more important than any of the subplots?
Do all the subplots serve the main plot?
Does the pacing vary?

title: Suspense
content: Check suspense and time pressure: the protagonist is in a seemingly hopeless race against time and/or running out of options, knows the consequences of failure, understands the extent of dangers/obstacles, the situation feels hopeless, and the story has a time lock and/or option lock.
items: Is the protagonist engaged in a seemingly hopeless race against time, and/or are they running out of options?
Does the protagonist know the consequences if they fail to achieve their objective?
Does the protagonist know the full extent of the dangers and obstacles before them?
Does the situation appear to be hopeless?
Does the story have either a time lock or an option lock?

title: Resolution
content: Check the ending and payoff: balance is restored and loose ends are tied up, expectations set by the premise are satisfied, the dramatic highpoint occurs near the end, the protagonist achieves the objective immediately after the climax, the resolution brings new awareness and illustrates the theme, the ending follows naturally (not tacked on), tone is consistent, and all plot threads are resolved.
items: Does the ending restore the balance and tie up loose ends?
Does the story satisfy the expectations set up by its premise?
Does the dramatic highpoint occur near the end?
Does the protagonist achieve their objective immediately after the climax?
Does the resolution result in a new awareness for the protagonist?
Does the resolution illustrate the theme?
Does the ending follow naturally from all preceding events, so it does not feel tacked on?
Is the tone of the ending consistent with the rest of the story?
Are all the plot threads resolved, leaving no loose ends?

title: Characterization
content: Check characterization and growth: characters drive the story and act from personality and will, are portrayed cinematically (not literarily) and are not stereotypical, traits/abilities are consistent and fit the story type, each character is vital with no duplicate roles, real-life texture and foils add dimension, and the protagonist has growth potential with a flaw—an internal transformational arc mirrored by the external journey—culminating in self-recognition/reversal that enables success.
items: Do the characters serve the story, and does the story derive from the characters?
Do the characters’ actions spring from their personality and will?
Are the characters depicted in a manner that is cinematic, not literary?
Are the characters original, not stereotypical?
Are the characters described in terms of their attitudes and personalities, not just their superficial traits?
Are the characters’ traits and abilities consistent with their roles?
Are these characters right for this type of story?
Is each character vital to the story, with no duplicate roles?
Do the characters have ordinary interests, hobbies, or occupations that make them seem real?
Are there foils to contrast and balance the scheme?
Are there bit parts to add dimension and color?
Do the principal characters have potential for growth?
Does the protagonist have a flaw that obstructs their efforts?
Is the protagonist’s internal, transformational arc mirrored in their external journey?
Does the protagonist experience a moment of self-recognition and reversal that enables them to finally achieve their objective?

title: Presentation and Point-of-view
content: Check presentation, point of view, and scene craft: focus on what matters most, choose the right start/end and perspective, POV originates from the character intended to carry the most empathy and stays consistent, scenes enter as late as possible and exit as soon as possible with a climax, and flashbacks/forwards/fantasies/dreams preserve empathy and are properly set up and motivated.
items: Does the script focus on what's most important?
Have I chosen the right places to begin and end the story?
Have I chosen the right perspective from which to tell this story?
Does the point-of-view originate from the character with the greatest intended empathy?
Is the point-of-view consistent?
Does each scene start as late as possible, rise to a climax, and end as soon as possible?
Does every flashback, flash-forward, fantasy, and dream sequence maintain our empathy for the main character?
Is every flashback, flash-forward, fantasy, and dream sequence adequately set up and motivated?

title: Exposition and Information
content: Check exposition and information control: convey enough information for understanding but not too much, keep exposition interesting and unobtrusive, ensure every bit is essential, withholding information for surprise feels natural, description is cinematic (only what can be seen/heard), and necessary terms/procedures are explained for lay audiences.
items: Does the script convey just enough information, but not too much?
Have I given audiences enough information for them to understand the story?
Is the exposition interesting and unobtrusive?
Is every bit of information essential for telling the story?
If critical information is being withheld for the effect of surprise, has it been done in a way that feels natural?
Is the description cinematic, detailing only what can be seen and/or heard?
Does the script explain all the terms and procedures that are needed for a layman to understand the story?

title: Setting
content: Check setting and use of time/place: time and place are used effectively and fit the story type, the timeframe supports the transformation, time progression and its effects are realistic, local color enriches the world, transitions are smooth and anticipated, montages are necessary, time passage is conveyed via action/imagery/sound (not superimposed legends), and the script is proofread for anachronisms and inaccuracies.
items: Are the time and place used effectively?
Is the setting appropriate for this type of story?
Is the amount of time during which the story takes place adequate to explain the amount of transformation that occurs?
Is the progression of time and its effects realistic?
Is the setting embellished with local color?
Does the story take full advantage of the time and place in which it is set?
Are the transitions from one time and/or place to another smooth and anticipated?
Is every montage necessary, quickly advancing the story in a way that could not be achieved with traditional scene structure?
Does the script use action, imagery, and/or sounds to convey the passage of time, without relying on superimposed legends?
Has an expert proofread the script for anachronisms and inaccuracies?

title: Details and Picturization
content: Check details and picturization: description guides the mind’s eye like a camera, is specific and kinetic, includes necessary details that naturally direct attention, every detail is relevant, cuts occur when scenes are complete (no arbitrary intercutting just to speed things up), camera movement is necessary, and the presentation style suits the material.
items: Does the description lead the mind’s eye in a manner that simulates the camera?
Is the description specific and kinetic?
Does the script include all the details needed to tell the story?
Do these details direct the audience’s interest in a way that seems natural?
Is every detail relevant and necessary?
Does every cut occur when the scene is complete, with no arbitrary intercutting just to quicken the pace?
Is every camera movement necessary?
Does the style of presentation suit the material?

title: Dialogue and Expression
content: Check dialogue and expression: every line serves the story and carries subtext, flows from character intentions, advances the scene, departures from the subject have a clear reason, dialogue is kept to a minimum, characters avoid bluntly stating feelings, dialect/slang is used appropriately, and personal direction is used only when absolutely necessary.
items: Does every line serve the story, and is there subtext?
Does every line flow from the characters’ intentions?
Does every line progress the scene?
Do the lines stay on subject? If not, is the reason for the departure apparent?
Has the dialogue been kept to a bare minimum?
Do the characters avoid openly stating their thoughts and feelings, thereby giving the lines subtext?
Have dialect and slang been used to spice up the language and flesh out the characters?
Is every instance of personal direction absolutely necessary?

title: Skipping the Preparation Phase
content: Writing without deliberate preparation (outline, character work, genre expectations) so the draft drifts.
root_cause: Jumping into pages before locking story focus, structure, character goals, and genre conventions.
fix: Draft an outline/beat map before pages
Write character bios (goals, flaws, relationships)
Review genre expectations to align structure/tone

title: Ignoring the Standard Screenplay Format
content: Not following professional screenplay formatting conventions, making the script harder to read and evaluate.
root_cause: Lack of familiarity with industry formatting or using a plain text editor.
fix: Use dedicated screenwriting software/templates
Learn basic formatting rules (scene headings, character cues, dialogue blocks)
Do a format pass before sharing

source.name: Greenlight Coverage
source.title: 13 Common Screenwriting Mistakes to Avoid

title: Creating Flat Characters
content: Characters lack depth, contradiction, or growth, so audiences struggle to invest emotionally.
root_cause: Not defining goals, fears, flaws, and relationships; no internal change across the plot.
fix: Define clear wants vs needs
Give flaws that create friction with the goal
Track an arc (belief/behavior) across major beats

source.name: Greenlight Coverage
source.title: 13 Common Screenwriting Mistakes to Avoid

title: Overloading the Story with Too Many Characters
content: Introducing more characters than the story can meaningfully develop, diluting focus.
root_cause: Adding roles that don’t drive plot/arc; not combining functions into fewer characters.
fix: Merge redundant characters
Ensure each character has a clear function (foil, obstacle, ally)
Prioritize a small set of arcs that support the premise

title: Lack of Character Motivation
content: Characters act without clear reasons, weakening believability and stakes.
root_cause: Goal, stakes, or values not defined; actions don’t logically follow from characterization.
fix: State protagonist’s objective plainly
Tie actions to values/fears
Make stakes concrete (what is lost if they fail)

title: Poor Dialogue Writing
content: Dialogue sounds unnatural, overly expository, or repetitive, reducing tension and pace.
symptoms: Dialogue explains feelings instead of implying them
root_cause: Writing what characters ‘need to tell the audience’ instead of what they’d say to win a scene.
fix: Give each speaker a distinct voice
Use subtext (characters want something)
Cut or compress lines that don’t change the scene
tags: Dialogue explains feelings instead of implying them

source.name: Greenlight Coverage

title: Overusing Parentheticals
content: Stuffing dialogue with acting directions/clarifications that clutter the page and constrain performance.
root_cause: Trying to control delivery instead of writing clear action and intention.
fix: Only use parentheticals when essential for meaning or addressee
Clarify intent via action and context
Trust actors/director to interpret

source.name: Greenlight Coverage
source.title: 13 Common Screenwriting Mistakes to Avoid

title: Writing Actions That Aren’t Visual
content: Describing internal thoughts or abstract states that can’t be filmed, reducing cinematic clarity.
root_cause: Leaning on prose/novel-style interiority instead of observable behavior.
fix: Convert interior states into observable actions/choices
Use props/environment to externalize emotion
Show consequences rather than explain

source.name: Greenlight Coverage
source.title: 13 Common Screenwriting Mistakes to Avoid

title: Relying on Clichés and Tropes
content: Using predictable situations/characters without a fresh angle, reducing originality.
root_cause: Copying familiar beats without adding a distinctive perspective or twist.
fix: Differentiate inspiration vs imitation
Add a unique premise angle or constraint
Complicate familiar tropes with character-specific stakes

title: Leaving Your Story Unfinished (or Too Neat)
content: Endings either fail to resolve promised arcs or resolve them too cheaply.

title: Formatting Errors
content: Misusing screenplay formatting conventions (e.g., CONT’D, O.C vs O.S, excessive transitions/camera angles).
symptoms: Overuse of CUT TO / camera angles
root_cause: Not using screenwriting software; not understanding when each notation applies.
fix: Use screenwriting software to handle formatting
Check O.C vs O.S in context
Keep transitions/camera angles minimal unless you’re directing

title: Lack of Character Development
content: Protagonist doesn’t meaningfully change, so the story feels stagnant.
symptoms: Same beliefs/behavior at end as beginning
root_cause: No defined internal need; no arc planned across beats.
fix: Give the protagonist an arc
Ask what’s different by the end
Design growth that the plot forces them to earn

title: When Structure Falls Apart
content: Acts/turns are uneven; inciting incident happens too early or too late, damaging pacing and engagement.
symptoms: Inciting incident around page ~30 (too late for many specs)
root_cause: Drafting without a beat sheet; misplacing major structural events.
fix: Create a beat sheet before drafting
Introduce protagonist before inciting incident
Aim inciting incident around ~page 13 (flexible)
Weave backstory gradually

title: Scenes Without Conflict or Purpose
content: Filler scenes lack conflict and don’t advance plot/character, slowing pacing.

Turn routine into a problem/choice that reveals character

title: Overusing Microdirection
content: Overly specific instructions for how actors should perform, limiting interpretation.
symptoms: Action lines like ‘a tear rolls…’ used as direction
root_cause: Trying to write performance beats as exact physical actions.
fix: Write emotional intent rather than exact action
Leave room for director/actors
Use microdirection sparingly, only when essential

title: On-the-Nose Dialogue
content: Characters say exactly what they think/plan, making dialogue feel lazy or unrealistic.
root_cause: Using dialogue to explain rather than to pursue objectives under pressure.
fix: Add subtext (characters want something)
Imply thoughts through behavior and conflict
Cut lines that exist only to explain

title: Lack of World Building

root_cause: Not choosing specific, story-relevant details; writing generic locations.
fix: Use 2–3 impactful visual details per setting
